Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Biomechanics of Vertical Clinging and Grasping in Primates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Doctoral student Laura Johnson (Duke University), under the supervision of Dr. Daniel Schmitt, will investigate the biomechanics of a specific set of primate postures - those adopted while vertically clinging to tree trunks. The research focuses on a key adaptive shift associated with the evolutionary origins of primates, that of the 'invasion' of the complex arboreal environment. Early primates evolved grasping hands and feet with nails, rather than keeping claws, such as found in other tree-dwelling species (e.g., squirrels). This evolutionary event of loss of claws raises a critical paradox for biomechanists, that of understanding how arboreal primates maintain an effective grip on large, vertical tree trunks without claws. The investigation of this question addresses morphological adaptation to an arboreal niche in both living and ancestral primates.

Not being able to take advantage of claws in the arboreal habitat, primates must hold onto the trees by using postures that will minimize muscular work. Prior research on mammalian biomechanics suggests hypothesized variation within three contexts involving differing musculoskeletal anatomies, substrate sizes, and body weights. To examine these variables, a sample of eight primate species from the Duke Lemur Center which differ in anatomies and body weights are observed in a laboratory setting. Individuals are prompted to vertically cling and grasp to substrates of four increasing sizes, relative to their body weight. The ground squirrel, Scurius caroliniensis, is included as a clawed non-primate mammalian outgroup. Video data are collected using an eight-camera system to document postures in three dimensions, and data on single-limb loading patterns are collected utilizing force plates inserted into the substrate.

Results from this study will shed light on the evolutionary pressures that led primates to lose claws in favor of nails, an adaptation that may be related to primate body size increase, and is a necessary precursor to human hand grasping. The project also incorporates undergraduate training and broad dissemination of data to other researchers and the public, including local K-12 schools, and will find application in zoo design and primate conservation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project entitled “Doctoral Dissertation Research: The biomechanics of vertical and grasping in primates” supported the dissertation research of a young female scientist—Dr. Laura Johnson—who is now a tenure-track anatomy professor at Ross University.  She teaches and continues an active research career, made possible in part by the support of this project. 

This project addressed key question about the origin and evolution of primates, the mammalian group to which humans belong.  The origin of primates occurred about 65 million years ago. It is thought that some early mammal group moved into an unoccupied ecological niche where it could move and search for food on thin, flexible, terminal branches of trees.  In association with the invasion of this arboreal environment, primates lost their claws and replaced them with flat nails.  There are a lot of theories why this change occurred.  But the focus of this dissertation was to explore a significant mechanical challenge faced by our earliest ancestors: how to move and forage in a habitat that includes large, vertical tree trunks without having claws to help dig into the tree.  Almost all primates—from small lemurs to large apes--engage in vertical clinging as an important part of their daily behavior and thus still face these challenges.  Some species habitually vertically cling and leap between supports.  How primates accomplish this task is unknown and probably varies with animal size and tree size. An animal vertically grasping to a small vertical tree trunk can curl the hands and feet around the entirety of the tree, but vertically clinging to a large tree trunk leaves an animal open to rotating or slipping backwards off the tree, requiring careful management of force production to maintain their grasp. Body mass should also have an effect on how primates cling because the increased weight would increase the force pulling the animal off the tree. This goal of this project was to provide the first data on how primates manage this feat and what it tells us about the challenges of their early evolution. A wide variety of primates from the Duke Lemur Center and were studied with 3-D video collection and force plates. 

This study found several significant and relevant patterns that help us understand primate anatomy and evolution. First, hind limb and forelimb postures differed.  Primates that spend much of their time vertically clinging and leaping use deeply bent limbs and hold their bodies close to the trunk compared to primates that spend more time running on branches. Foot posture showed little variation, showing how important foot position is for all animals on vertical support.  Forelimb postures were more varied. Second, during clinging, species were shown to bear the majority of their weight in their hindlimbs relative to their forelimbs, suggesting that hindlimb forces are key to maintaining posture and would have been important in early primates. Another important result is that all species tend to prefer smaller substrates, clinging less frequently for shorter durations as substrate size increased, suggesting early primates without claws would have spent time on small supports. Hand posture changed as size increased.  Primates grasped with their thumb (pollex) on smaller substrates, but the thumb disengaged on larger substrates. Taken together, the finding that the forelimb held a range of postures on each substrate size for all species and played a limited role in weight-bearing suggests the forelimb was free to move so that early primates could reach out for new supports or food. This provides insight into the overall anatomy of the earliest primates and their behavior in the trees.
